title: Mallinckrodt Nets Government Support for $1.6 Billion Opioid Deal
summary: The drugmaker will place its generics business in bankruptcy as part of a proposed deal with thousands of local governments and 47 states and U.S. territories. Drugmaker Mallinckrodt PLC said on Tuesday that it reached a settlement worth more than $1.6 billion with 47 states and U.S. territories and lawyers representing thousands of local governments to settle liabilities stemming from the opioid addiction crisis.

title: MTA Board Member Named Interim Head of New York City Transit Authority
summary: Sarah Feinberg, a former Obama rail-safety official, succeeds the popular Andy Byford. A former Obama administration rail-safety official has been named interim head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's subway and bus systems.

title: Yield on 10-Year U.S. Treasury Note Hits Record Low
summary: Benchmark bond yield settles at 1.328%, breaching previous low set in July 2016. The yield on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note fell to an all-time low Tuesday as stocks swooned for a second straight day, driven by worries the coronavirus could seriously disrupt an already sluggish global economy.

title: Comcast Wraps Up Deal for Free-TV Service Xumo
summary: Xumo is one of small number of companies that offer free, ad-supported streaming video services for internet-connected TVs. Comcast Corp. said Tuesday it had acquired streaming video company Xumo LLC, bolstering its offerings for free, ad-supported digital video

title: Weinstein Conviction Is a Lifeline for District Attorney
summary: Cyrus Vance gets boost as possible re-election bid nears after criticism over prosecution record. The conviction of Harvey Weinstein provided a boost for Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr., whose three terms have been marred by criticism that he has failed to prosecute sex crimes and treated the rich and powerful with deference.

title: Tesla's Driver-Assistance Autopilot Draws Safety Scrutiny
summary: National Transportation Safety Board urges closer oversight of car-automation features. U.S. safety investigators leveled a blistering rebuke of the federal regulator responsible for overseeing the safety of Tesla Inc.'s advanced driver-assistance system called Autopilot, which they found contributed to another fatal crash.

title: Small Texas Cities Sued Over Abortion Bans
summary: ACLU says anti-abortion 'sanctuaries' are violating the Constitution. The American Civil Liberties Union is suing seven small rural cities in eastern Texas that enacted ordinances declaring it crime to procure or perform abortions in their jurisdictions.

title: Promoting a Balanced Take on U.S. History
summary: The battle for history on America's historical battlefields is part of a much larger war for history that is all but over.. Regarding Michael Pillsbury's "George Washington's Birthday and the Battle for History" (op-ed, Feb. 15): One hopes that Mr. Pillsbury's plea for Congress to demand restoration of a more respectful and positive interpretation of the nation's most important historical sites won't fall on deaf ears, but intercession seems unlikely. Critics of Mr. Pillsbury's interpretation of the courage, sacrifices and contributions of leaders and soldiers in the 18th and 19th centuries will insist that his is a whitewashed version of history that leaves out all of the victims of the nation's earliest atrocities.

title: Bloomberg: Doomed Exemplar of Capitalism?
summary: Mike Bloomberg should be proud of his achievements and he is a shining example of why capitalism provides unlimited opportunities.. Kimberley A. Strassel's Bloomberg Says Me Too to Leftism" (Potomac Watch, Feb. 21): There's something deeply wrong in America when successful entrepreneurs have to apologize for creating a new company that employs thousands of people. It's especially disturbing when the criticism comes from Bernie Sanders who has made millions of dollars in politics creating zero jobs. As uncovered in the book "Profiles In Corruption" by Peter Schweizer, Sen. Sanders has made millions by having his wife set up a media-buying company for his advertisements. This company was established purely to profit from huge spending by the Sanders campaign. This is the very definition of the so-called swamp.

title: Afghan President to Postpone Start of Term Amid Election-Fraud Concerns
summary: Questions threaten peace process; U.S. poised to sign deal with Taliban. WASHINGTON-Afghanistan's president agreed to postpone the start of his second term after the U.S. warned that concerns about fraud had undermined the vote and threatened the nascent peace process, the State Department said Tuesday.

title: Barr Urges Lawmakers Not to Weaken U.S. Spying Powers
summary: Attorney general says he is considering ordering a range of requirements to address report faulting FBI probe of Carter Page.

title: Oh Come on, Oh Come On, Mayor Emanuel
summary: Rahm Emanuel is right, the slogan was great. But when people dig into the plans of even the moderates, they will see massive tax increases on working-class citizens to pay for all that free lunch.. Rahm Emanuel's "Bernie Sanders, Insider" (op-ed, Feb. 21) makes a passing reference to Michigan's Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's promise to "fix the damn roads" as an example to which Democrats calling themselves moderates should aspire. But that catchphrase hid the truth about Gov. Whitmer and, similarly, the so-called moderate Democrats' plans. After averring in a debate that the suggestion that she would need to raise gas taxes by $0.20 a gallon was "ridiculous," she proposed in her first budget an increase of $0.45 a gallon. To attempt to get her way, she line-item vetoed a budget passed in the legislature with broad bipartisan support, eliminating funding for veterans, autistic children and school children. She admitted, even, that much of her new tax to fix those roads wasn't for fixing or even for roads. Mr. Emanuel is right, the slogan was great. But when people dig into the plans of even the moderates, they will see massive tax increases on working-class citizens to pay for all that free lunch. One hopes that Michigan voters in 2020 don't make the same mistake as in 2018.

title: The Pope's Celibacy Ruling Ignores Important Issues
summary: Letting priests marry and having women become deacons wouldn't in any way "bend its teaching to the times.". Tim Busch and Mary Rice Hasson's "The Pope is Catholic After All" (Houses of Worship, Feb. 14) totally ignores the reality the Roman Catholic Church is faced with, at least in the U.S. I have been a practicing Catholic for over 70 years and have seen the Catholic Church's ability to service its flock deteriorate steadily over the past few decades. When I was young, we had several young priests in our parish to assist the pastor. I haven't seen a priest under 40 in years, and our current priest is in his 80s. When I visit my hometown of Pittsburgh, I've noticed that the diocese keeps consolidating parishes and closing churches.

title: Environmental Groups Sue U.S. Over Lightbulb Energy Standards
summary: Natural Resources Defense Council, the Sierra Club and the Consumer Federation of America argue for phasing out incandescent bulbs. WASHINGTON-Environmental groups led by the Natural Resources Defense Council sued the Trump administration on Tuesday over its decision to keep energy-efficiency requirements for household incandescent lightbulbs at their current level.

title: First U.S. Testing Begins for Potential Coronavirus Drug
summary: NIH-sponsored study of experimental Gilead drug includes American patient evacuated from Diamond Princess cruise. Researchers have begun the first study in the U.S. of an experimental drug aimed at treating the novel coronavirus, the National Institutes of Health said Tuesday.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Law on Urging Noncitizens to Stay in U.S. Illegally
summary: Justices consider free-speech arguments against government efforts to control U.S. borders. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court wrestled Tuesday with a clash between free-speech principles and the government's effort to control U.S. borders, weighing whether a federal law that makes it a crime to encourage or induce noncitizens to stay in the country illegally is constitutional.

title: Streaming Surge Turns Recorded-Music Sales Up to $11 Billion
summary: Revenue grew 13% in 2019 to the highest point in more than a decade, with streaming accounting for 80% of overall revenue. Recorded-music sales in the U.S. grew 13% last year to $11.1 billion-their highest point in more than a decade-as revenue continued to surge from streaming services such as Spotify and Apple Music.

title: Fed's Kaplan: Unclear Right Now Coronavirus Calls for Rate Change
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas president says that events around the outbreak are still too fluid to say whether interest rates should be cut. Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan said Tuesday events are still too fluid around the coronavirus outbreak to say the U.S. central bank needs to lower short-term rates, as many in financial markets now think is likely.

title: Fed's Wait-and-See Posture Tested by Virus
summary: Top Fed official says it is too soon to determine the full impact of the virus. WASHINGTON-A top Fed official said Tuesday it is too early to tell whether the coronavirus outbreak will force the central bank to resume rate cuts in the coming months.

title: Tupperware Shares Plunge as Company Delays Annual Report
summary: The consumer-products seller discloses accounting probe, warns of profit pressures. Tupperware Brands Corp. shares plunged Tuesday after the consumer-products company warned of pressure on its sales and profit and said an internal accounting probe would delay the completion of its annual report.

title: Hot Pockets Scion Given Five-Month Prison Term in College Admissions Case
summary: Michelle Janavs agreed to pay $300,000 to cheat daughters' way into college. BOSTON-A federal judge sentenced Hot Pockets heiress Michelle Janavs to five months in prison Tuesday for agreeing to pay $300,000 to give two daughters an illegal edge in college admissions.

title: New Jersey Governor's Budget Would Boost Aid for Schools, Pensions, Rails
summary: Phil Murphy's $40.8 billion proposal includes compromise to edge him closer to a millionaires tax. New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy called for pumping more money into education, mass transit and the state's beleaguered pension system in a $40.8 billion budget proposal.

title: Amazon Opens Cashierless Supermarket in Latest Push to Sell Food
summary: The e-commerce giant is also looking into licensing the checkout-free technology to rival retailers. Amazon.com Inc. rolled out its checkout-free "Go" technology in a large grocery store and plans to license the cashierless system to other retailers.

title: Supreme Court Tosses Cross-Border Shooting Lawsuit
summary: Court's 5-4 decision says U.S. legal claims against officer not allowed for cross-border shooting. WASHINGTON-An ideologically divided Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that U.S. Border Patrol agents can't be held liable for damages for shooting people on the Mexico side of the southern U.S. border.

title: Hosni Mubarak, Egyptian Autocrat Ousted in Popular Uprising, Dies
summary: Heavy-handed governance sparked a 2011 revolt that removed him from power and spawned a violent era of political upheaval. CAIRO-Egypt's former President Hosni Mubarak, whose three decades of autocratic rule sparked the popular uprising that would catalyze an era of revolution and war across the Arab world, died Tuesday. He was 91.

title: As Markets Shudder, Individual Investors Stand Their Ground
summary: For many individual investors, market dips have become events to wince at, but not panic over. News of a rapidly worsening coronavirus epidemic sent stocks from London to Hong Kong tumbling and government bond yields skidding to record lows.

title: U.S. Stock Losses Mount
summary: Treasury yields hit new bottom, Nasdaq's 2020 gains vanish as markets signal growing virus concern. A rout in global financial markets deepened Tuesday, sending the Dow Jones Industrial Average down nearly 900 points and heightening the anxiety of investors around the world.

title: Tokyo Olympics Could Be a Victim of the Coronavirus, IOC Official Says
summary: As outbreaks of the coronavirus spread, IOC member Dick Pound raises the possibility of cancellation or postponement of the Games. Athletes who have been training for years are months away from the pinnacle of their sporting lives.

title: This Stock Has Returned 4,100% Since Housing Crash
summary: Owners of mobile-home parks have trounced the broader market thanks to soaring house prices, nimbyism and tenants who can't move out. One of the best-performing investments since last decade's housing crash: trailer parks.

summary: People will consider evidence that in the past doomed cases in the era of #MeToo, experts say. The conviction of Harvey Weinstein reflects an evolving cultural understanding of the nature of sexual assault and opens the way for women to pursue complaints of sexual misconduct in the courts and at work, experts and advocates say.

title: FanDuel Founders, Former Employees Sue Over Getting Nothing in Deal

FanDuel's founders and more than 100 former employees say the company's board of directors and private-equity investors intentionally undervalued the sports-betting operator to shut them out of an acquisition deal, according to a lawsuit filed Tuesday.

Now, a rival luxury hotel next door is alleging that the Waldorf stole corporate secrets and personal information about some of those VIP guests in an effort to win more of that business.

title: The Taj Mahal, Folk Dancers, 'Hey Jude': Trump's 36 Hours in India
summary: President and Prime Minister Modi celebrate their relationship, sidestep trade issues. But his diplomatic drop-in was as intense as it was brief, with his hosts providing expansive red-carpet treatment that the president used to celebrate the most politically favorable stretch of his presidency.

title: JPMorgan Won't Shun the Fed's Discount Window Anymore
summary: Move is likely to lessen stigma associated with borrowing directly from central bank. JPMorgan Chase & Co. title: Iran's Deputy Health Minister Contracts Coronavirus
summary: Death toll from the virus rises to at least 15 in Iran with around 1,000 people being tested for the infection. title: Oil Extends Fall on Coronavirus Fears
summary: Investors still trying to gauge the fallout from virus. Oil prices fell again Tuesday, weighed down by investors' concerns about how the spread of the coronavirus outside China will affect global oil demand.

summary: Look below the surface of the S&P 500 and the market mostly reflected investors' concerns. Or did equities just react in a reasonable way to the rapid spread of Covid-19 in South Korea and Italy over the weekend?

title: The Most Delicious Way to Cook Cauliflower
summary: Roast half of it for deep umami flavor and give the rest a quick simmer to keep it delightfully vital. The result is a satisfying vegetable ragout to serve over pasta. ON DAYS OFF, most chefs want to be anywhere but the kitchen. Philip Krajeck is an exception. "I'm a dad and I love to cook," he said. While you won't find this warming winter pasta on the menu at either of Mr. Krajeck's Nashville restaurants, it wins rave reviews from his family. His second Slow Food Fast recipe combines rigatoni with cauliflower, anchovies, chile flakes, garlic and Parmesan. Fresh parsley and crunchy fried breadcrumbs provide color and contrast.

title: Two Juul Executives Leave Company in Pullback Overseas
summary: E-cigarette maker has scaled back plans in several countries after criticism of its marketing, regulatory pressure. Two executives overseeing international regions for Juul Labs Inc. are departing the e-cigarette maker as it scales back its overseas operations, the company said.

title: Potatoes, Butter, Salt: A Recipe You'll Commit to Memory
summary: The Swiss know cold-weather cooking. Exhibit A: rösti, the world's most comforting potato pancake and a masterpiece of simplicity. Rösti recipes spark the same fierce debate in Switzerland that chocolate chip cookie recipes do in the U.S. A flattened disc of shredded potatoes cooked in fat until crisp on the outside and tender and creamy within, rösti is served whole or in slices-and few people wish to stop at one. Who could possibly argue with-or about-that?

title: Trump Criticizes Justices Sotomayor, Ginsburg
summary: President says they should recuse themselves from cases involving him. summary: Governments increasingly order telecoms to turn off web access in neighborhoods, regions or whole countries, sometimes for months. title: Coronavirus Arrives Unfashionably Early During Italy's Fashion Shows
summary: How Italy's growing number of confirmed cases disrupted the style industry's biannual events in Milan. AS I WAITED to go through customs at Milan's Malpensa airport, en route to the women's fashion shows that kicked off Feb. 18, a man in a mask and surgical gloves flashed a light at my forehead with a thermometer gun to take my temperature digitally. Behind me, throngs of other sleepy, black-garbed fashion types were arriving for the shows. Like migrating birds in trench coats, twice a year they fly in from all around the world, rolling their hard-ridged Rimowa suitcases filled with carefully chosen outfits layered between sheets of tissue paper.

summary: Fifth Wall closes $100 million fund to invest in online retailers looking to open physical stores. A real-estate-focused venture-capital firm said it has closed a $100 million fund to invest in companies born online that are looking to join the bricks-and-mortar world.

title: The Coronavirus Scare: This Time Is Different
summary: Even if health authorities get a grip on the outbreaks, counting on an economic and market recovery may be wishful thinking. This is the first column in a five part Heard on the Street series about the market and economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic.

title: Cars.com CTO Boosts Staff Cloud Skills in Move to Amazon Web Services
summary: AWS will drive Cars.com's new website. Cars.com LLC is retraining its information technology staff as the online vehicle marketplace shifts operations from co-located data centers to Amazon.com Inc.'s cloud service.

title: Democratic Debate: What to Watch With Sanders as the Front-Runner
summary: A look at what's at stake in South Carolina as the presidential candidates again meet. South Carolina is a make-or-break state for former Vice President Joe Biden, who was the national Democratic primary front-runner for much of 2019 but who has watched Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont rack up a delegate lead after the first three contests. Because the state doesn't permit early voting, Tuesday night's debate could significantly influence people who are still making up their minds ahead of Saturday's voting.

title: China's Virus Censorship and Propaganda Draw Backlash
summary: The fast-spreading Covid-19 epidemic has stirred a flood of negative opinion about the Communist Party's handling of the crisis. To shape public opinion about China's response to the deadly new coronavirus, Beijing has turned to a trusted strategy: deploying a massive propaganda campaign and suppressing critical news coverage.

title: Coronavirus Could Bring Back Bad Memories for Chip Makers
summary: A business recovery for memory-chip makers like Samsung could be derailed by the spreading epidemic. Chip makers are among the companies most vulnerable to the coronavirus. The epidemic could bring back some bad memories.

title: Japan Breathes New Life Into a Centuries-Old Investment Idea
summary: Tontines, which had their heyday over 300 years ago, are enjoying a revival among those who fear they will outlive their savings. TOKYO-A controversial centuries-old investment arrangement, often used as a plot device in murder mysteries, is experiencing a resurgence in Japan as a savings vehicle designed for the era of longevity.

title: More States Consider Free Tampons in School Bathrooms
summary: Wave of student activism helps fuel bills in more than a dozen states. In schools around the country, more girls are making the same request: free tampons.

title: How AI Can Detect Child Predators Online-Before They Attack
summary: New initiatives aim to protect young people when they chat with strangers online, but can the bots get ahead of the bad guys?. When Rhiannon McDonald was 13, she was chatting online one night with someone she thought was a female modeling scout. In a matter of hours, from the computer in her bedroom, she was coerced into sending numerous photos of herself unclothed-and providing her home address.

title: China Sentences Bookseller Gui Minhai to 10 Years in Jail
summary: Beijing reinstates Swedish national's Chinese citizenship, underscoring the tenuous legal status of Chinese-born foreign citizens. HONG KONG-A Chinese court sentenced a bookseller who was born in China and held Swedish citizenship to 10 years in jail on espionage charges, and said his Chinese nationality had been reinstated, underscoring Beijing's increasing forcefulness in asserting jurisdiction over foreign citizens.

title: Disney CEO Bob Iger Steps Aside; Parks Chief to Take Helm
summary: Chapek has led Disney Parks since 2015; Iger to stay on as executive chairman. Robert Iger stepped aside as chief executive of Walt Disney Co. , though he will retain significant power over the company that he expanded into Hollywood's biggest and most powerful entertainment conglomerate over a more than 14-year tenure.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'Facebook: The Inside Story' Review: The Path to Domination
summary: As it grew, Facebook was helped by knowing what apps its users were exploring, generally without users being aware of the surveillance.. There are 7.8 billion people on planet Earth. Over a third of them use the Facebook platform each month and around 2.3 billion use at least one of Facebook's services each day, according to the company's most recent earnings call. By serving as the fabric connecting billions of users and delivering so much content that they "Like," is Facebook making the world a better place, as the company contends, or is it doing harm, by addicting us to manipulative clickbait while amplifying poisonous voices and invading our privacy? As veteran technology journalist Steven Levy explains in "Facebook: The Inside Story," it's complicated.

title: Coronavirus's Global Spread May Not Be Contained, WHO Says
summary: Number of new cases in China declines, but it isn't clear whether outbreak can be stopped from spreading globally, World Health Organization says. The World Health Organization said Monday it isn't yet clear whether the coronavirus can be stopped from spreading further globally, as growing outbreaks in Italy, South Korea and Iran heightened concerns.

title: Mallinckrodt Pitches at Least $1.6 Billion Opioid Settlement, Generics Unit Bankruptcy
summary: The Ireland-based company is proposing a settlement of opioid-related liabilities that would put its U.S. generic-drug business in chapter 11 bankruptcy. Drugmaker Mallinckrodt PLC is finalizing a settlement proposal worth at least $1.6 billion that would place its U.S. generic-drug business into bankruptcy to address coming debt maturities and liabilities stemming from the opioid crisis, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Harvey Weinstein Convicted of Some Sex Crimes, Acquitted of Others
summary: Hollywood producer is taken to New York City jail after verdict; sentencing set for March 11. Harvey Weinstein was found guilty of sex crimes involving two women but acquitted of the most severe charges he faced, a mixed verdict that nevertheless means the Hollywood producer faces the prospect of a lengthy prison term and delivers a victory to the #MeToo movement.

title: As Coronavirus Cases Rise, South Korea's Response Is Criticized
summary: More than 760,000 people sign petition calling for ban on all Chinese travelers. South Korea's efforts to tackle the coronavirus epidemic are being criticized for both moving too quickly and not fast enough, a dizzying backlash as the country struggles to tame the fast-spreading illness.

title: Lawmakers Pressure U.S. Indian Health Service to Release Sex-Abuse Report
summary: Report focuses on the IHS's failure to protect children from abuse during the nearly 30-year-career of pediatrician Stanley Patrick Weber. Lawmakers who oversee the U.S. Indian Health Service are demanding the health care agency release a report on its mishandling of a pedophile doctor that it wants to keep confidential, saying the agency must be held accountable.

title: HP to Buy Back $15 Billion in Stock to Battle Xerox Takeover Bid
summary: For the quarter, HP reports a 16% decline in profit to $678 million, or 46 cents a share. HP Inc. pledged to buy $15 billion of stock, with at least $8 billion of that in the first year, to tackle a hostile takeover bid from Xerox Holdings Corp.

title: A Market Pandemic
summary: Investors get the coronavirus jitters, but please hold the panic.. The World Health Organization (WHO) still hasn't declared the novel coronavirus a global pandemic, but you wouldn't know it from Monday's convulsions in financial markets. The economic slowdown that started in China is now infecting global supply chains, and the economic harm may be broader than predicted.

title: A Place for Meaningful Cultural Conversations
summary: A revamped Seattle Asian Art Museum organizes its collection along thematic, instead of geographic, lines with special attention paid to outside voices..

title: California's Janus Jiu Jitsu
summary: A lawsuit challenges a state law banning advice on paying union fees.. The Supreme Court ruled in Janus v. Afscme (2018) that government employees cannot be compelled to subsidize union speech. California Democrats quickly undercut this First Amendment landmark by forbidding government officials from talking about worker speech rights.

title: Bernie's Cuba Illiteracy
summary: The Vermont Senator finds a silver lining to the Castro revolution.. As Bernie Sanders advances closer to the White House, his beliefs and policies may finally get the scrutiny they deserve. An example was an interview on CBS 's "60 Minutes" Sunday when the 78-year-old socialist waxed effusive over Cuban literacy.

title: The Train That Ran Over Boris Johnson
summary: The British Prime Minister falls for a high-speed rail boondoggle.. U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson this month endorsed a new high-speed rail line between London and the north of England. As a tale of the temptations facing a politician urgently trying to boost the economy, it doesn't get more cautionary than this.

title: Così Restaurant Chain Enters Bankruptcy for Second Time Since 2016
summary: The fast-casual dining chain said it would increase its focus on catering after closing 30 stores in December. Fast-casual dining chain Così Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection for the second time since 2016, saying it would place a greater focus on catering after closing 30 of its soup-and-sandwich restaurants.

title: Fear of Coronavirus, Rather Than Virus Itself, Hits Economies
summary: Estimates of the epidemic's impact on the global economy are largely educated guesses. The body's immune response to infection is often more painful than the infection itself. The same is true of epidemics and the economy.

title: Drugmaker Ships First Experimental Coronavirus Vaccine for Human Tests
summary: Clinical trial is expected to start in April, as epidemic originating in China spurs quick response. Drugmaker Moderna Inc. has shipped the first batch of its rapidly developed coronavirus vaccine to U.S. government researchers, who will launch the first human tests of whether the experimental shot could help suppress the epidemic originating in China.

title: SEC Rethinks Approach to Conflicts Among Bond Raters
summary: Agency is seeking industry input on how to combat rating inflation as 2010 fix falters. LAS VEGAS-The Securities and Exchange Commission's top official overseeing credit-rating firms said Monday the agency is rethinking its post-crisis effort to improve the quality of bond ratings, a tacit acknowledgment that the decade-old program has been a failure.

title: FAA Tightens Training Requirements for Airline Pilots
summary: New rule calls for command and mentoring training for captains. U.S. aviation regulators are mandating enhanced training for airline pilots, from newly hired first officers to veteran captains, culminating years of debate over how to improve cockpit decision-making and leadership skills.

title: Shake Shack's Customer Traffic Weakens
summary: Hamburger chain issues warning about next fiscal year after quarterly same-store sales fall 3.6%. Shake Shack Inc. struggled to draw in customers in its latest quarter and warned sales growth might decline next year.

title: New York City Faces Backlog of Background Checks on Employees
summary: Among employees allowed to start jobs without being fully vetted was former education official David Hay, who was charged with child sex crime. New York City's Department of Investigation needs four years to clear up a backlog of background checks on thousands of city employees, the commissioner said Monday, saying the agency has limited staff and resources to process them.

title: Payments Business Revolut Valued at $5.5 Billion in New Funding Round
summary: The total raised is now $836 million; company will start offering services in the U.S. this year. Revolut Ltd., one of the fastest-growing upstarts in the hot U.K. digital banking and payments market, was valued at $5.5 billion after it raised $500 million in new funding from venture capitalists.
